summary: A New York Times article detailing allegations that Jeffrey Epstein relied on a network of women, including his girlfriend Ghislaine Maxwell and several employees, to recruit and manage teenage girls and young women for sexual abuse. The article reports on the ongoing federal investigation into these associates following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the case, accused of running a sex-trafficking ring and sexually abusing underage girls. Died by suicide in jail in August 2019.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Accused in multiple lawsuits of overseeing efforts to procure girls for Epstein, managing his homes, and being at the top of the alleged hierarchy.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.role: Epstein's employee, alleged recruiter and scheduler
persons.context: Accused in lawsuits of scheduling girls for sex with Epstein and managing the logistics of his encounters. Named as a possible co-conspirator in the 2008 Florida plea deal.

persons.name: Haley Robson
persons.context: Recruited as a teenager, then allegedly recruited other girls from her high school for Epstein, earning $200 per girl. Now under scrutiny by federal authorities.

persons.name: Lesley Groff
persons.context: Worked for Epstein for nearly 20 years, managing his schedule and allegedly arranging travel for girls. Named as a possible co-conspirator in the 2008 plea deal.

persons.name: Adriana Ross
persons.context: Named as a possible co-conspirator in the 2008 plea deal. Allegedly removed computers from Epstein's Florida mansion during the police investigation.

persons.name: Nadia Marcinkova
persons.role: Former model, pilot, and associate of Epstein
persons.context: Named as a possible co-conspirator in the 2008 plea deal. Accused of participating in sexual encounters with Epstein and underage girls.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts Giuffre
persons.context: Said she was recruited at age 16 by Maxwell and became Epstein's 'sex slave,' also forced to provide sexual favors to his acquaintances.

persons.name: Sarah Ransome
persons.context: Sued Maxwell and other associates, alleging she was sexually abused by Epstein and given instructions by Maxwell and Kellen on how to please him.

persons.name: Teresa Helm
persons.context: Spoke at a court hearing, urging prosecutors to investigate the women in Epstein's inner circle who helped him.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Prosecutor whose office brought charges against Epstein and stated the investigation into the sex-trafficking conspiracy was not finished after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Janusz Banasiak
persons.context: Described Maxwell as 'the boss' in a deposition and testified about Ross removing computers.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: Described Maxwell as 'the boss' in a deposition.

persons.name: David Rodgers
persons.context: Said in a deposition that Sarah Kellen was 'like an assistant to Ghislaine.'

persons.name: Spencer T. Kuvin
persons.context: West Palm Beach lawyer who represented several accusers and commented on Sarah Kellen's role.

persons.name: Michael Bachner
persons.context: Stated his client never engaged in misconduct or knowingly made travel arrangements for anyone under 18.

persons.name: Lauren Hersh
persons.context: Commented on the legal complexity of charging associates who may have initially been victims themselves.

persons.name: Douglas McIntosh
persons.context: Represented Robson in a civil case and called her 'a lovely young lady' but declined to answer questions about her involvement with Epstein.

persons.name: Robert Maxwell
persons.role: British publishing magnate, father of Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as Ghislaine Maxwell's father.

persons.name: Amy Julia Harris
persons.context: Byline for the New York Times article.

persons.name: Frances Robles
persons.context: Byline for the New York Times article.

persons.name: Mike Baker
persons.context: Byline for the New York Times article.

persons.name: William K. Rashbaum
persons.context: Byline for the New York Times article.

connections.description: Described as partners in business, with Maxwell allegedly orchestrating the procurement of girls and managing his homes.
Kellen was a high-ranking employee accused of scheduling girls for sexual encounters with Epstein.
Pilot David Rodgers described Kellen as 'like an assistant to Ghislaine.'
Robson would receive calls from Kellen to arrange for girls to give massages to Epstein, and they would hammer out logistics.
Robson was initially recruited as a teenage victim, then became a recruiter for Epstein.
Groff was Epstein's executive assistant for nearly 20 years, managing his schedule and allegedly arranging travel for girls.
Ransome alleges Maxwell and Kellen gave her tips on how to sexually please Epstein.
Ransome alleges Kellen and Maxwell gave her tips on how to sexually please Epstein.
Giuffre says she was recruited at age 16 by Maxwell with promises of travel and education.
Accused of participating in sexual encounters with Epstein and underage girls.
Ross was an assistant to Epstein who allegedly removed computers from his mansion during a police investigation.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in a Manhattan jail cell, leading federal authorities to refocus their investigation on his associates.

events.title: Victim Impact Hearing
events.description: About two dozen women offered searing accounts of sexual abuse by Epstein at a hearing in federal court in Manhattan to dismiss the indictment posthumously.

events.title: Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein struck a plea deal with federal prosecutors in Florida, pleading guilty to state charges and serving 13 months in jail. The deal granted immunity from prosecution to four women: Sarah Kellen, Lesley Groff, Adriana Ross, and Nadia Marcinkova.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Investigation
events.description: Palm Beach police investigated Epstein, during which computers were allegedly removed from his mansion by Adriana Ross.

events.title: Haley Robson Deposition
events.description: Haley Robson gave a deposition in a civil case describing her recruitment by Epstein and her subsequent role as a recruiter for him.

keyFacts: Following Epstein's suicide, federal authorities refocused their investigation on more than half a dozen employees, girlfriends, and associates who allegedly helped feed his appetite for underage girls.

Four women—Sarah Kellen, Lesley Groff, Adriana Ross, and Nadia Marcinkova—were named as possible 'co-conspirators' and granted immunity in Epstein's 2008 Florida plea deal, but could still face charges in Manhattan.
Ghislaine Maxwell is accused in multiple lawsuits of being at the top of a hierarchy that procured girls for Epstein, with Sarah Kellen acting as a 'lieutenant' who scheduled the encounters.
Haley Robson, recruited as a teenager, later became a recruiter herself, bringing girls from her high school to Epstein's Palm Beach mansion for $200 per girl.
The article highlights the legal complexity of charging associates like Robson and Marcinkova, who may have initially been victims themselves before being used to recruit others.
